body:
I'm still not comfortable in general on grouping unrelated JIRAs into a single PR. Any reason this wasn't 2 PRs?

Also, are the invalid/error topics being created?
Removed all changes related to METRON-279.
I took the liberty to also add a unit test to ensure that the _enrichment_ configs also serialize and deserialize properly.

Can we please not call this METRON-154, since METRON-154 is about decoupling indexing from enrichment and this is not that?  I do understand that this might be a prerequisite task, but if we could create another JIRA and maybe link the two JIRAs to express the relationship.
Done
Does it need METRON-154 in order for this to work?  Is there a hard dependency?  Should i wait to validate this until all the pieces are ready?

@james-sirota This is completely independent, can be merged in as-is, and has value outside of just METRON-154.

I did a bunch of work for METRON-154 previously that was effectively lost based on how much the code base has diverged.  Really my own fault for not getting it done, but I'd like to merge in chunks of it a time, so that doesn't happen again.

So, if I'm not mistaken, METRON-279 was reported because the parser_invalid and parser_error topics were not created during deployment. The root cause was the duplicated roles causing confusion. So, unless I'm mistaken, METRON-279 won't be complete unless those topics are created by the deployment scripts. It's kind of buried in the commentary, but perhaps Neha can confirm/deny that.
+1 looks good to me.
+1, thanks!
Is there documentation outside of the file that you forgot to attach?  Or the docs that you are referring to are comments in the code?
Added creation of parser_error and parser_invalid topics as part of standard deployment. These are needed per METRON-223.
Just in the code; javadoc.
+1 great job
+1, looks good. Thanks!
+1 glad to have this. Puzzled why west stopped working though. I'll try to remember to dig into that. Think it's worth a Jira?
+1, looks good!

Thanks. I wasn't sure if it deserved a JIRA or not.  Since it works in all AWS regions except us-west-2, I was assuming that it is more likely to be something about my AWS environment and not something that is Metron specific.  On the other hand, I don't really know.  It could be a Metron problem.
I ran this up in AWS and it worked ok.  Did anyone else check?
Just for posterity, I ran it up in vagrant

I've been trying, but it's AWS is fighting me.

That said- I'm +1 by inspection.

+1.  In the future can you please name the PR starting with the full JIRA name followed by the description, like so: "METRON-321: Add items to .gitignore".  The full JIRA name (with the dash) triggers comments to be copied from the PR to the JIRA and the full description helps me know what the heck it is without going to the JIRA. ;)
Great contribution, thanks!  I had a few comments, but good job. :)
Whoops, forgot, we should probably have a unit test addition given this functionality.
+1, by inspection
+1 by inspection
+1, by inspection
+1, by inspection
+1 by inspection
+1, by inspection
+1, looks good.
Apologies about the titles missing text - did github defaults change bc I don't recall having to set that before?
Closing this PR - We are going to take a different approach on Centos 7 support.
+1 by inspection
Closing this PR - this will instead be included as part of another merged PR

Why do we not have a separate PR per JIRA?

It appears that the various tasks have various authors, wouldn't it be better to have each author submit their own JIRA so that they can be listed on the commit?

Also, this isn't the complete set of tasks for METRON-214, so when we close this JIRA, it won't be the complete body of work for METRON-214, just a portion.

That's a good question. If we don't squash this pr prior to committing, will that give the authors the proper credit?

On the second, this is the completion of METRON-214.

Ok, after some out of band discussion, this is fine..lots of small subtasks that had a lot of interdependency.  I'm +1 upon inspection.

EDIT: forgot to mention, in exchange for the authors rebasing to be a JIRA per commit, we'll forego the commit squashing which will allow for proper attribution of tasks to be made.
added test case

Hi @ajayydv - it looks like you created this PR on your METRON-227 branch. Can you please separate METRON-227 from this PR, look into why the travis check fails and add "Global Batching & flushing" to the title?

Thanks!

+1 looks good. 
Ran it up in EC2 and Vagrant.
+1 Nice work

Initial Travis build, from before the cache is populated, downloads everything
https://travis-ci.org/justinleet/incubator-metron/builds/145862346#L174

Afterwards, on a whitespace commit no longer downloads the dependencies
https://travis-ci.org/justinleet/incubator-metron/builds/145870931#L171

+1 (non-binding)
28 min vs 27:40... I had hoped this would have made a bigger impact

The timings are really inconsistent in general. Some builds (essentially the same) earlier were taking anywhere as low as 17 minutes.  Earlier a pull into master took almost 30. It makes it hard to tell how worthwhile timings are, even in close proximity.
+1, worked and created a 975MB cache.
+1 via inspection.  Great job, Justin.
+1 all tests pass.

To test, ensure Docker is installed and ready for builds
Ensure the metron-platform is at least packaged (no code is added to metron-platform, so skipping the tests should be acceptable).
From the main directory:
`mvn clean package -DskipTests`

Afterwards, navigate to metron-deployment and run:
`mvn clean package`

A docker image should be built if it's the first run, then run with a script to create the RPMs.  They will be copied to the standard target folder.

On followon runs, the Docker container should mostly be skipped and will create the same RPMs.

After the run, RPMs should be available in /target/RPMS/noarch.

Hi,

Thanks for the contribution. Is there a reason you prefer brew over pip?

@dlyle65535 It's mostly about consistency I think, but it should also be easier (not impossible) to manage the multiple ansible versions inside homebrew than with pip. Include both sets of instructions?
I don't really have a strong preference, just curious.

How about using Storm's built-in tick tuples for this?

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/storm-user/8addaQm3OT4/0OQfSgQkRwEJ
@mmiklavc That is absolutely what the tick tuple was designed for. What are the pro/con versus the current proposed approach?

It is a much simpler design and it leverages Storm's built-in mechanisms for performing actions like DB flushes. Also, you don't have to worry about multi-threading in your bolt if you want to flush prior to your buffer being full when you haven't received a tuple in a while. e.g. I have 99 tuples and need 100 for a flush, but don't receive a tuple for n minutes - without using tick tuples, you either just sit and wait, add a thread that needs to check internally, or add another external bolt with a clock. 

I'm not aware of any cons to using the TT approach. This is what tick tuples were built for.

There is one downside that I see, but I think it's acceptable.  We currently keep configuration around the indexing in zookeeper so that the topology configuration can be adjusted on the fly in a running topology.  This would externalize that and keep the tick frequency in flux, so to change it would require a topology restart.

I think that this is acceptable, but it's worth pointing out.

Honestly, we don't want ANY of those flux topologies for the parsers anymore.  They should be removed from the RPM as well as from the underlying project.  Is there a JIRA to complete the removal of these?
@cestella That's an excellent point. I saw the test.yaml files didn't belong, but in reality we're not using any of this. I'll modify the Jira and PR to reflect this.
I get ya, yeah, we have half the instructions in brew and then the ansible switching in pip.    Sounds good, I'm +1.
+1 looks good
+1, ship it!

Change Visualisation options as:

WMS URL: http://ows-tile.terrestris.de/osm-basemap/service? 
WMS Layers: OSM-WMS
WMS Version: 1.3.1
WMS format: image/png

@jaidrao  - Kibana has added their own tile service with friendly ToS in Kibana 4.5.3. This PR is intended to version lock the default version of Kibana to 4.5.3 to make sure we stick with that version. There's nothing preventing users from substituting the map server of their choice.

Overall, looks great- one small thing:

Testing fails on docker-machine and boot2docker because of permission issues on docker volumes.
Testing passes on Docker for Mac.

You may want to call that out in the README. Otherwise, I'm +1, good job!
Good catch. I've added a note to the README calling out the Docker Toolbox vs. Docker for Mac issue, and updated this PR.
+1 This is super nice.  I am using Docker for Mac and was able to successfully build all of the RPMs.  I was then able to successfully install all of the RPMs on a CentOS 6 box.
Easiest way to test this is to run the SquidParserTest unit test.
+1 by inspection

This looks really good, @mmiklavc  I suspect you meant Ansible above? Perhaps you can re-title this to "Enable topology classpath to be updated via configuration"?
I'll run it up tomorrow morning and let you know.
It's a setting in Ambari that exposes the functionality, which is set via the Ansible scripts. I will rename it per your recommendation.
Thanks- it'll help later when we modify the Ambari setup scripts to accept the setting. :)
+1. Ran it up on EC2- worked great!

Hello, has anyone had issues with org.apache.metron.enrichment.integration.EnrichmentIntegrationTest hanging? It seems to be trhowing the same exception over and over again which cause Travis CI to kill the build. I've looked at builds that were successful. The ones I've checked also have this error, just not this many times. Also, I'm having trouble reproducing it locally. Has anyone seen this before?
+1 by inspection, great job!
Bump?
+1, works as advertised! :)
+1 by inspection

Hi JJ,

Thanks for taking this on. Looks great! One small thing, could you look at moving the repeated group vars (e.g. hdp_stack, hdp_repo_def and the ambari variables) to defaults in the appropriate roles?

Also, since you are in the neighborhood: METRON-43 could be satisfied by removing the passwd_less_ssh role. Since it's no longer needed anyway, rather than update it to reflect these changes, how would you feel about a twofer?

Hello David,

Thanks for the feedback. I moved the group_vars to defaults. Also, I squashed my commits to make it easier to read. I also deleted the passwd_less_ssh role as well.
Outstanding. Great work! How did you test this, full_dev on Vagrant?
Thanks, I appreciate it. Yes, I tested this with full_dev on Vagrant. I followed this [documentation](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/METRON/Verifying+Builds).
Sorry Dave!  I was sleeping on the job.  +1 by inspection, this looks good

What is the reasoning to have Stellar not share a common parent package?  We have org.apache.metron.common.dsl, also org.apache.metron.common.query, org.apache.metron.common.transformation.  Aren't all these packages focused on Stellar?  Maybe org.apache.metron.common.stellar?
Why is there still both a PredicateProcessor and a TransformationProcessor?  Can't we unify these?

@nickwallen There is no longer an org.apache.metron.common.{transformation,query} and there is, as part of this PR an org.apache.metron.common.stellar.  Not sure where you're seeing these packages continuing to exist.
Oops, maybe i checked out the wrong PR.  That would explain a lot.

@nickwallen There is still a PredicateProcessor because having a stellar function which acts as a predicate is a sensible differentiation from a stellar function which returns an arbitrary function.  Just as there is a java.util.function.Function and a java.util.function.Predicate and they are distinct.  They both reuse a base class, however.

I will defend the org.apache.metron.common.dsl package.  That is intended to be utilities for domain specific languages (like variable resolvers, etc).  My intention was to open up the possibility to reuse across _other_ DSLs that we might need going forward.

Understand your reasoning on DSL package. Personally, I would collapse 'org.apache.metron.common.dsl' under the stellar package.  If we're going to use it a different way in the future then we can make that change in the future.  But right now, it just confuses the simplicity of having a single parent stellar package.
